messageBody:
Hi James,

On 5/21/07, James Abley <james.abley@...> wrote:
>
> On 21/05/07, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...> wrote:
> >
> > > IÂ´m just using to return values. Does anyone here has used it for something
> > > else?
> >
> > I'm /typically/ using RMock in quite the opposite way, I use the mocks
> > to create expectations on the mock. The methods that I expect to be
> > called /typically/ has void as return-type.
> >
> > Those expectations in essence replace asserts in those tests so the
> > mocks are not just tools that allow me to respond with data to the
> > class I'm testing and then assert; they exist in order to make sure
> > that the correct things are passed along from the class I'm testing to
> > the class I mocked given the stimuli I provide in my test.
>
> Can you point to an example? I'm not sure whether I'm already using
> something like that, but it's always good to see what works for other
> people.

Here's an example from my book that uses a similar mock object library
(EasyMock) both for verifying expected collaboration (method
invocations) and for faking the return values:

public class OrderProcessorEasymockTest {

@Test
public void testOrderProcessorWithEasyMock() {
float initialBalance = 100.0f;
float listPrice = 30.0f;
float discount = 10.0f;
float expectedBalance = initialBalance - (listPrice * (1 -
discount / 100));
Customer customer = new Customer(initialBalance);
Product product = new Product("TDD in Action", listPrice);

PricingService mock = createMock(PricingService.class);
expect(mock.getDiscountPercentage(customer,
product)).andReturn(discount);
replay(mock);

OrderProcessor processor = new OrderProcessor();
processor.setPricingService(mock);
processor.process(new Order(customer, product));

assertEquals(expectedBalance, customer.getBalance(), 0.001f);
verify(mock);
}
}

I hope this helps.

Lasse
